article.description: Join Autharva | CISOevents at RSAC for a private executive roundtable on AI agents, identity governance, audit readiness, and CISO accountability. Featuring expert panels, curated networking, fine food, drinks, and music at AWS Builder Loft, San Francisco.

markdownDescription:
On March 23 (5:00–8:30 PM PT), at the AWS Builder Loft in San Francisco, [**Autharva** ](https://autharva.com)**| CISOevents** will convene a private, invite-only executive connect : **AI Agents, Identity & Accountability — The New CISO Playbook**.

RSVP here: [https://events.builder.aws.com/WaoLzn](https://events.builder.aws.com/WaoLzn)

As enterprises accelerate AI adoption, autonomous AI agents and Non-Human Identities (NHIs) are transforming cloud security, governance, compliance, and executive accountability. This exclusive forum is designed for CISOs, security architects, GRC leaders, and legal counsel building secure, audit-ready AI-driven environments.

And while the dialogue will be rigorous and practitioner-led, the evening will begin on a refined note  with curated food, premium drinks, and great music setting the tone during high-impact discussions.

## Why AI Changes the CISO Mandate

AI agents are no longer passive tools. They are autonomous actors capable of initiating workflows, accessing systems, and making decisions across enterprise infrastructure.

This shift is redefining:

* **Cloud security architecture**
* **Identity and access management (IAM)**
* **AI governance and GRC frameworks**
* **Legal liability and regulatory exposure**
* **CISO accountability models**

Traditional cloud cost and security models were built around predictable workloads and human-controlled identities. AI agents disrupt that foundation. They scale dynamically, generate unpredictable compute patterns, and operate beyond conventional identity governance frameworks.

For today’s CISO, the challenge is clear: secure not just systems, but autonomous digital actors.

Autonomous systems are rewriting enterprise rules. Our panels break down exactly how leaders must respond.

## Architecture Panel: Why AI Broke the Cloud Cost Model

The Architecture panel explores how autonomous AI agents are disrupting traditional cloud infrastructure, cost predictability, and identity design. AI workloads scale dynamically, trigger API chains independently, and introduce new infrastructure components that were never designed for autonomous actors.

Leaders such as [Arjun Sharma of IBM ](https://www.linkedin.com/in/arjun-sharma-40b8b545/)will unpack how to build agent-aware architecture that balances performance, cost optimization, and security resilience. The discussion will focus on visibility into Non-Human Identities (NHIs), secure infrastructure adaptation, and designing systems that anticipate autonomous behavior rather than react to it.

***

## Legal Panel: Do’s and Don’ts for CISOs in the Age of AI

As AI agents act independently, legal exposure increases. This panel addresses the rapidly evolving regulatory landscape surrounding AI governance, liability, and executive accountability.

Technology litigator [Jessica Nall](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jess-nall/) of Withers and former FBI counterintelligence operative [Eric O'Neill](https://www.linkedin.com/in/eric-m-oneill/), Founder of NeXasure, will provide clarity on documentation standards, incident readiness, and how CISOs can defensibly demonstrate oversight of AI-driven actions. The focus: turning governance from a policy statement into legally defensible control.

***

## GRC Panel: If AI Is Audited Tomorrow, Would You Pass?

Audit readiness in an AI-enabled enterprise demands more than traditional compliance checklists. This panel examines the new governance expectations regulators and boards are placing on AI systems.

With insights from [Laura Sawka](https://www.linkedin.com/in/laura-sawka/) of Sawka Advisory and Dipali Vasandi of Tata Consultancy Services, the session will explore audit trails for AI agents, mapping AI actions to accountable human owners, and ensuring compliance frameworks extend to every Non-Human Identity. The goal is practical guidance on building governance that withstands regulatory scrutiny.

***

## CISO Executive Roundtable: Who Is the Ultimate Beneficiary of Agentic Actions?

The closing executive discussion tackles the defining leadership question of the AI era: when autonomous agents create value — or cause harm — who ultimately benefits, and who bears responsibility?

Enterprise security leaders including [Matt Bunch ](https://www.linkedin.com/in/matt-bunch-6019b513/)of Tyson Foods, [Harpal Harika](https://www.linkedin.com/in/hharika/) of REPAY, and [Wendy Turner-Williams](<https://Wendy Turner-Williams>) of SymphraAI will share real-world insights on ownership models, board oversight, and embedding accountability across the AI agent lifecycle.

## Autharva’s Framework for Identity Security

Led by [Abhishek Bansal, CEO of Autharva,](https://www.linkedin.com/in/uscgradabhishekbansal/) and Elaine Doyle, Chief Trust Officer, Autharva delivers a practical framework for governing AI agents and Non-Human Identities.

The platform enables organizations to:

* Discover and catalog AI agents across cloud environments
* Assign clear human ownership to every autonomous identity
* Secure AI-driven infrastructure components
* Ensure governance, compliance, and audit readiness
* Manage the full AI agent lifecycle

In the AI era, identity is the new control plane — and governance must extend to every non-human actor.

## Writing the Future of  Identity Security

AI agents are redefining cloud security, identity governance, compliance strategy, and executive accountability.

The modern CISO must evolve — governing autonomous systems, securing Non-Human Identities, and ensuring audit readiness in a rapidly shifting regulatory environment.

This is not about reacting to change. It is about defining the new CISO playbook for AI agents, identity, and accountable enterprise leadership.

An evening of high-signal dialogue, curated executive peers, exceptional hospitality, and meaningful exchange awaits. If you are shaping AI, identity, or enterprise security strategy, we invite you to apply to attend.

RSVP here - [https://events.builder.aws.com/WaoLzn](https://events.builder.aws.com/WaoLzn)
title: AI Agents, Identity & Accountability — The New CISO Playbook

article.description: Every year, millions of students pay ₹2 lakh+ to consultants who hand them copy pasted SOP's and disappear after payment. I built AIRA AI a free AWS powered study abroad assistant that generates personalized SOPs, matches universities using real admission data, and simulates actual US visa officer interviews using voice AI giving every student the same unfair advantage.

markdownDescription:
*Category: Social Impact*

### My Vision — Let me be real with you.


I  have a friend. Smart guy. 3.4 GPA. Good GRE score. Genuine dream of studying Computer Science in the US. He paid ₹1.8 lakh to a consultant.

He got into his university. But at the visa interview?

He froze.

The officer asked him one simple question: "Why can't you study this in India?"He had never practiced that question: The consultant never told him it was coming.

Rejected. In under 5 minutes.

After ₹1.8 lakh. After 4 years of hard work. After everything.

I was sitting next to him when he got the call. That broke something in me.That moment is why AIRA AI exists.

So I built AIRA AI.

AIRA AI is the world's first Agentic Consular Assistant — a full AI-powered study abroad co-pilot that does everything a ₹2 lakh human consultant does, but better, faster, and free.

Here is what AIRA AI can do right now:

→ Generate a hyper-personalized Statement of Purpose (SOP) that sounds like YOU not a template

→ Generate professional Letters of Recommendation written from your recommender's perspective

→ Match you with universities based on your actual GPA, GRE, TOEFL scores using real admission data from 30 top US universities

→ Track your application status 24/7 with intelligent monitoring

→ Simulate a real US Visa Officer interview — voice to voice — with Officer Smith asking you the exact questions that trip students upI built this during the AWS 10,000 Ideas Competition using Kiro as my agentic IDE and the AWS ecosystem as my backbone.

***

### Why This Matters

####

Every year, over 13 million students from India and across the developing world dream of studying abroad.

Most of them never make it.

Not because they are not smart enough.
Not because their scores are bad.

But because the system is designed to be expensive, confusing, and gatekept by people who charge ₹1.5 to ₹3 lakh just to fill a few forms.

Let me put this in perspective: The average Indian family earns ₹3-4 lakh per year. Consultants charge ₹1.5 lakh just to help apply. That is 50-60% of a family's annual income.

Just to apply.
Not even to get in.
Just to apply.

And what do students get for that money?

A copy-pasted SOP.
A panicked 30-minute visa prep call.
A consultant who disappears after payment.

AIRA AI changes this completely.

For zero rupees, a student anywhere in the world can now:
✓ Get a personalized SOP that reflects their actual story, their actual goals, their actual voice
✓ Practice their visa interview until they are confident with a strict AI visa officer who does not go easy on them
✓ Know exactly which universities to apply to based on real admission data not gut feeling
✓ Never miss a deadline or status update because the system watches for them 24/7This is not just an app.

This is access.
This is equity.
This is what happens when you give every student the same tools that rich students take for granted.

***

### How I Built this

*Architecture Overview:* AIRA AI is built as a multi-agent system on AWS, with a React frontend deployed on Vercel and an intelligent backend powered by AWS services.Here is how each piece works:

**1. The Application Agent — Powered by Amazon Bedrock**

* The heart of AIRA AI is the Application Agent.
* This agent uses Amazon Bedrock with Claude Sonnet for high-reasoning writing tasks. It does not just fill a template it understands the student's story through their profile data and constructs a narrative that is uniquely theirs.
* The agent is trained on a Knowledge Base built in Amazon Bedrock containing hundreds of successful SOP samples and admission patterns from top universities. This gives it the institutional knowledge of a seasoned consultant.
* When a student fills their profile GPA, GRE, work experience, research papers, career goals the agent synthesizes all of this into an 800-1000 word SOP that follows the exact structure admissions committees want to read:
* A compelling opening hook
* Specific academic achievements with context
* Professional experience with quantified impact
* Why this exact university and program
* Clear career vision
* What they bring to the cohort

The same agent generates Letters of Recommendation from the recommender's perspective something no template-based tool has ever done well.

**2. The Visa Officer Agent — Amazon Nova Sonic**

* This is our WOW feature.
* Using Amazon Nova Sonic for real-time voice interaction, AIRA AI simulates a strict US visa officer Officer Smith.
* The student selects their difficulty level:
  Easy, Medium, or Hard.

Then Officer Smith speaks.Real questions. Real pressure. Real simulation.Hard level questions include things like:

* "Your bank statement shows funds that appeared
  recently. Explain this."
* "You worked at Google. Why leave a high paying
  job to study?"
* "How do we know you will return home?"

After the interview, the system analyzes:

* Clarity Score
* Confidence Score
* Return Intent Score
* Financial Credibility Score
* Overall Visa Approval Probability

This is not a chatbot asking questions.
This is genuine preparation that could be the difference between a visa approval and a heartbreaking rejection.

**3. The Status Guard — AWS Lambda**

* Nobody should have to manually check 5 university portals every single day for months.
* The Status Guard is a serverless monitor built on AWS Lambda that checks application portals around the clock and alerts students the second a status changes.

No more refreshing portals 10 times a day.
No more anxiety of missing an update.
The system watches. You live your life.

**4. Data Layer — Amazon DynamoDB**

* All student profiles, application data, SOP history, and interview results are stored in Amazon DynamoDB.
* This gives AIRA AI persistent memory the AI remembers your profile, your history, your progress across months of interaction.
  Just like a real consultant would.

**5. Frontend — React + AWS Amplify**

* The frontend is built in React with a premium design system Plus Jakarta Sans typography, indigo-violet color palette, glassmorphism effects on the login page.
* It is deployed via AWS Amplify with CI/CD pipeline connected to the repository.
* The entire architecture runs on the AWS Free Tier, proving that world-class AI tools do not require enterprise budgets. Go to Universities enter your GPA and GRE, see which of 30 universities you qualify for

**Development Milestones:**

Week 1: Core architecture and university database Built the 30-university database with real admission data. Implemented weighted admit chance calculator.
Week 2: SOP and LOR generation Integrated Amazon Bedrock Knowledge Base. Achieved consistent 800-1000 word output quality.
Week 3: Voice Interview Integrated Amazon Nova Sonic. Built Officer Smith persona with 20 rigorous questions across 3 difficulty levels.
Week 4: Polish and deployment Premium UI redesign. Mobile responsiveness. Deployed to production.
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

### DEMO

**Live Application:** [https://aira-ai-chi.vercel.app](https://aira-ai-chi.vercel.app/)

**Key Features to Try:**

Login with Demo access — instant, no signup

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIOmv6UG0ChGsnRMFf2eMp2L1K/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x693" caption="Login with Demo access — instant, no signup" />

***

Dashboard — see your complete study abroad overview

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIOxesTPYu0MCT7jmL7mD3ZUDV/Scre.webp?imgSize=953x988" caption="Dashboard — see your complete study abroad overview" />

***

Universities — search with your GPA and GRE scores, get admit chance predictions

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIP53x66ttqFZMakcr7C8Gq65T/Scre.webp?imgSize=955x1000" caption="Universities — search with your GPA and GRE scores, get admit chance predictions" />

***

Profile — build your academic profile, get your Visa Readiness Score and see exactly which universities you qualify for

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPAcAAlcxxAkmOALDWR2bsPcl/Scre.webp?imgSize=766x929" caption="Profile — build your academic profile, get your Visa Readiness Score and see exactly which universities you qualify for" />

***

Applications — track all your applications with Status Guard monitoring 24/7

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPGWuok0jENvJBYD20RyXoSqB/Scre.webp?imgSize=944x994" caption="Applications — track all your applications with Status Guard monitoring 24/7" />

***

SOP Generator — generate your 800+ word personal statement in seconds

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPQ1VgRr0Aej8DcO22AftQDzu/Scre.webp?imgSize=874x995" caption="SOP Generator — generate your 800+ word personal statement in seconds" />

***

LOR Generator — create a professional recommendation letter instantly

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPW5xxCIAM0KBpat69bK7QLLd/Scre.webp?imgSize=952x984" caption="LOR Generator — create a professional recommendation letter instantly" />

***

Mock Interview — practice with Hard level visa officer questions and get scored

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPav9l6ptwOjpiU5sJSPtPXbb/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x659" caption="Mock Interview — practice with Hard level visa officer questions and get scored" />

***

Voice Interview — speak directly to Officer Smith and get real-time feedback

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIPfKIDRFzUUxau1tDB7HRxbQn/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x466" caption="Voice Interview — speak directly to Officer Smith and get real-time feedback" />

***

## What I Learned

Building AIRA AI taught me things that no computer science course ever did.

**1. The problem is harder than the code.**

I spent week one thinking about architecture. But the real challenge was understanding why students fail their visa interviews — not just what questions are asked, but what psychological patterns interviewers are looking for.

I had to become a visa expert before I could build a visa tool.

**2. Amazon Bedrock changes what is possible for solo founders.**

Before Bedrock, building an intelligent document generation system would have required a team of ML engineers, months of training, and significant
infrastructure costs.

With Bedrock's Knowledge Bases and Claude Sonnet, I was able to create a system with genuine institutional knowledge — trained on real successful SOPs — in days, not months.

This is the democratization of AI.

**3. Voice AI is still the frontier.**

Integrating Amazon Nova Sonic showed me just how powerful and how challenging real-time voice AI is. The latency, the speech recognition accuracy,
the natural conversation flow — these are hard problems. But when it works, the experience is genuinely magical. A student speaking to an AI visa officer and getting real feedback on their confidence level is unlike anything else.

**4. Real impact requires real data.**

The most important decision I made was using real university admission data actual GPA requirements, actual acceptance rates, actual deadlines instead of placeholder content.When a student sees that their profile gives them a 65% admit chance at Georgia Tech and a 23% chance at MIT, they trust the system.That trust is everything.

**5. Kiro changed how I build.**

Using Kiro as my agentic IDE was a completely different development experience. The ability to describe a feature in plain language and have it implemented across multiple files simultaneously while maintaining context about the entire project compressed weeks of development into days.

This is what building with AI feels like.
And it changes everything.

***

### Final Thought


There is a student somewhere right now in a small town in Andhra Pradesh, or Gujarat who has a 3.2 GPA, a decent GRE score, and a genuine dream of studying in the US.

She cannot afford a consultant. She does not know which universities to apply to. She is terrified of her visa interview. She has never spoken to anyone who has been through this process.

AIRA AI was built for her.Not for the students who already have every advantage. For the ones who have the dream but not the resources.
If AIRA AI helps even one student get their visa approved one student who would have been rejected without the preparation then every line of code was worth it.

That is the mission.
That is why this matters.
That is AIRA AI.

\#aideas-2025 #social-impact #APJC

***

*Built with ❤️ by Rohan Reddy*
*Solo Founder — AIRA AI*
A*WS 10,000 Ideas Competition*
*Category: Social Impact*

Live Demo: [https://aira-ai-chi.vercel.app
](https://aira-ai-chi.vercel.app/)

title: AIdeas: AIRA AI — I Let an AI Reject Me 500 Times

article.description: A real-time cybersecurity platform engineered to detect phishing with precision and transparency. By combining browser forensics, AI-driven language analysis, infrastructure intelligence, and a deterministic risk engine, it delivers unified threat visibility and explainable decisions—empowering enterprises to stop attacks before damage occurs.

markdownDescription:
## **PhishGuard: A Deterministic and Explainable Hybrid Architecture for Real-Time Phishing Detection**

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIK2DUAxagAiG5ynTnqodSwJX4/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x673" title="Cost Of Modern Phishing" zoom="true" vAlign="center" />

## **App category**

Workplace Efficiency

## **My Vision**

Modern phishing no longer looks like the obvious scams of the past. In 2022, a major financial services organization suffered a credential-based phishing breach that bypassed email filtering, endpoint protection, and URL reputation systems. The attacker used a newly registered domain with a valid HTTPS certificate, absent from blacklists, and visually identical to Microsoft’s authentication page. Within minutes of an employee entering credentials, internal tools were accessed, inbox rules were created, MFA settings were modified, and lateral phishing campaigns were launched. The breach remained undetected for nearly 36 hours.

This incident reflects a broader reality: traditional defenses are designed to detect known threats. They rely heavily on historical intelligence—blacklists, signatures, and static rules. While effective against previously identified malicious domains, they struggle against newly deployed infrastructure that operates within legitimate web standards.

Machine learning-based content detection improves generalization by analyzing URL structures, lexical patterns, and page content using techniques such as TF-IDF, deep neural networks, and anomaly detection. However, many of these approaches function as probabilistic black boxes, offering limited explainability—an issue in enterprise environments where auditability and trust are critical.

Infrastructure-focused detection methods go deeper by examining relationships between domains, IP addresses, certificates, nameservers, and Autonomous Systems. Graph-based techniques like centrality analysis, clustering, and embeddings can uncover coordinated campaigns. Yet, these approaches are often used offline for investigation rather than integrated into real-time prevention systems.

My vision with PhishGuard was to bridge these gaps.

I wanted to build a system that does not rely solely on blacklists, nor depend entirely on opaque machine learning predictions. Instead, PhishGuard combines:

* Real-time credential flow detection
* Content-based machine learning analysis
* Infrastructure-aware graph intelligence
* Deterministic and explainable risk aggregation
* Cloud-native, event-driven architecture for scalable processing

Rather than detecting threats after compromise, PhishGuard is designed to identify suspicious credential-harvesting behavior and coordinated infrastructure patterns at the moment of access.

The goal is clear: shift phishing defense from reactive detection of known threats to proactive, explainable prevention of emerging infrastructure-level attacks.

## **Why this matters?**

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIKV272ONC3SLIAXmA3g58cSyB/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x570" title="Why This Matters" zoom="true" />

PhishGuard’s threat model is grounded in how modern phishing actually works—not in outdated assumptions about malware or obvious malicious domains.

Today’s attackers can register domains in minutes, obtain valid SSL/TLS certificates for free, and deploy phishing pages on reputable cloud infrastructure. From a technical perspective, these domains often look legitimate. They use HTTPS, clean hosting providers, and polished brand replicas. There is no exploit, no malware payload—only social engineering and trust manipulation.

This matters because traditional defenses were not built for this reality.

When a domain is:

* Newly registered
* Not yet present in blacklists
* Using valid SSL
* Hosted on trusted infrastructure

Reputation-based systems have nothing to flag. Signature-based detection fails because there is no known signature. By the time threat intelligence feeds update, the campaign may have already rotated domains and harvested credentials.

The assumption that attackers reuse infrastructure components—such as hosting IPs, certificates, nameservers, ASNs, or registrars—is critical. While domains may change frequently, underlying operational patterns often remain consistent due to automation frameworks and cost efficiencies. By modeling these relationships as a dynamic graph, PhishGuard detects structural similarity across campaigns—even when surface-level indicators differ.

This approach shifts detection from superficial domain evaluation to deeper infrastructure-level correlation.

Most importantly, the security objective of **pre-compromise prevention** directly addresses the real cost of phishing:

* Credential theft happens within minutes
* Lateral movement can begin immediately
* Detection often occurs hours later

If a system only alerts after credentials are entered, the damage may already be done.

PhishGuard is designed to:

* Detect credential-harvesting behavior at access time
* Identify coordinated infrastructure patterns
* Escalate risk deterministically and explainably
* Block submission when confidence is high

This matters because prevention is fundamentally different from response.

In enterprise environments—where regulatory exposure, financial loss, and reputational damage are at stake—real-time, explainable decision-making is not optional. It is necessary.

By modeling realistic adversary capabilities and focusing on infrastructure-aware, deterministic prevention, PhishGuard addresses the gap between how phishing operates today and how many systems still attempt to defend against it.

PhishGuard was engineered with three uncompromising goals:

* **Real-time prevention**
* **Infrastructure-aware intelligence**
* **Deterministic and explainable decision-making**

The system was designed as a layered, cloud-native architecture on AWS to balance sub-second blocking with deep asynchronous intelligence processing.

## **How we Build This**

PhishGuard is structured into five coordinated layers:

* **Browser Forensic Agent**
* **Fast Path Detection Layer**
* **Intelligence & Graph Processing Layer**
* **Deterministic Risk Aggregation Engine**
* **Event-Driven Cloud Orchestration Layer**

This separation ensures immediate protection while enabling scalable backend intelligence.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIKvxNry91tzLu4JzVbyOZiPmr/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x579" title="PhishGuard" zoom="true" />

## **Frontend / Detection Layer**

### **Browser Forensic Agent (Chrome Extension)**

The extension performs structured DOM inspection at page load and extracts forensic signals without performing local classification.

### **Extracted Signals**

**Form Behavior**

* Login form detection
* Password field presence
* External form submission targets
* Hidden input fields
* Password fields embedded in iframes

**Script Indicators**

* External script count
* Unique script domains
* Suspicious script domains

**DOM Manipulation Indicators**

* Disabled right-click
* Obfuscated HTML
* Excessive iframe count

**Content & Brand Signals**

* Brand keyword detection
* Urgency scoring
* URL-domain mismatch detection

### **Key Design Decision**

* No risk classification occurs client-side
* Structured JSON is transmitted to backend
* Centralized and auditable detection logic

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AILFJZtKcwmECeoJPyPc6FVnjB/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x656" title="Frontend" zoom="true" />

## **API & Orchestration Layer**

### **Amazon API Gateway**

* Routes all browser requests
* Integrates with AWS WAF for perimeter protection

### **AWS WAF**

* Protects backend APIs from malicious traffic
* Provides additional request filtering

### **AWS Lambda (Fast Path Engine)**

* Executes lightweight detection logic
* Enables sub-second response without idle infrastructure
* Handles:
  * Known malicious domain checks
  * Lightweight heuristic scoring
  * Reputation feed matching
  * Cache lookups

##  **Database & Persistence**

### **Amazon RDS (PostgreSQL)**

Stores:

* Scan results
* Domain intelligence metadata
* Infrastructure relationships
* Campaign clustering data
* Deterministic findings history

### **Amazon ElastiCache (Redis)**

* Provides in-memory caching
* Enables \<300ms repeated domain scans
* Reduces repeated ML and graph computation
* Improves latency under load

## **Intelligence Layer**

### **Amazon ECS Fargate (Containerized ML & Graph Compute)**

Executes heavy workloads including:

* NLP inference
* GNN embedding generation
* Infrastructure similarity computation
* Campaign clustering
* Graph recalculation
* Deep domain enrichment

Runs only when deep analysis is required.

## **Infrastructure Graph Engine**

PhishGuard maintains a directed graph modeling:

* Domains
* IP addresses
* SSL certificates
* Nameservers
* Autonomous System Numbers (ASNs)
* Registrar patterns

### **Graph Processing Includes:**

* PageRank centrality analysis
* Community detection
* Campaign clustering
* Graph Neural Network (GNN) embeddings
* Similarity search against known malicious clusters

### **Key Advantage:**

* Detects structurally related phishing domains
* Identifies coordinated infrastructure reuse
* Goes beyond surface-level URL inspection

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AILSVnOJfKr6ugzQX9DNALapYn/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x525" title="AI" zoom="true" background="dark" />

## **Deterministic Risk Aggregation Engine**

PhishGuard does not allow black-box ML outputs to directly classify risk.

Instead, it uses a mathematically bounded layered scoring framework.

## **Layer 1 – Content Risk**

| content\_risk = model\_scoreWhere: 0 ≤ model\_score ≤ 1 |
| ------------------------------------------------------- |

***

## **Layer 2 – Infrastructure Risk**

| infrastructure\_risk =(graph\_score × 0.40) +(reputation\_risk × 0.30) +(domain\_intelligence × 0.30) |
| :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |

***

## **Layer 3 – Deterministic Boost Rules**

* Known malicious domain:

| infrastructure\_risk = max(infrastructure\_risk, 0.9) |
| ----------------------------------------------------- |

* Newly registered domain (\< 7 days):

| infrastructure\_risk = min(infrastructure\_risk + 0.15, 1.0) |
| ------------------------------------------------------------ |

* Fast-flux DNS behavior:

| infrastructure\_risk = min(infrastructure\_risk + 0.25, 1.0) |
| ------------------------------------------------------------ |

* Campaign clustering detected:

| infrastructure\_risk = min(infrastructure\_risk + 0.20, 1.0) |
| ------------------------------------------------------------ |

***

## **Layer 4 – Final Score Fusion**

| final\_score =(content\_risk × 0.5) +(infrastructure\_risk × 0.5) |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------- |

***

## **Layer 5 – Escalation Safeguards**

If:

| model\_score ≥ 0.9 AND suspicious\_tld = true |
| --------------------------------------------- |

Then:

| final\_score = max(final\_score, 0.8) |
| ------------------------------------- |

***

## **Risk Classification Thresholds**

* ≥ 0.75 → HIGH
* ≥ 0.45 → MEDIUM
* \< 0.45 → LOW

## **Confidence Calculation**

| confidence = 1 − \|content\_risk − infrastructure\_risk\| / 2 |
| ------------------------------------------------------------- |

Overrides:

* Known malicious domains enforce confidence ≥ 0.95
* Fast-flux detection cannot result in LOW classification

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AILujzoyVhGlLxoHoboXM4Z4xJ/Scre.webp?imgSize=680x450" title="System arch" zoom="true" />

## **Fast Domain-Only Mode (Pre-Navigation Blocking)**

For ultra-low-latency blocking:

final\_score = infrastructure\_risk

* Enables \<300ms pre-navigation blocking
* Does not wait for full content analysis

## **Explanation Engine**

Output is constructed strictly from triggered findings.

Structured output format:

\{
"risk": "HIGH | MEDIUM | LOW",
"confidence": float,
"summary": "...",
"findings": \[...],
"advanced": \{
"domain\_age\_days": int,
"gnn\_similarity": float,
"campaign\_id": string,
"registrar": string}
}

Key principles:

* No fabricated reasoning
* All explanations derived from triggered signals
* Fully auditable
* Enterprise-compliant transparency

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIMCbu2zsueXwbwgVFNAHgTnNZ/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x702" title="AWS " zoom="true" />

## **Event-Driven Cloud Orchestration**

### **Amazon SQS**

* Decouples ingestion and enrichment
* Enables asynchronous deep processing
* Provides fault tolerance
* Supports dead-letter queues

### **Amazon EventBridge**

* Schedules:
  * Threat feed ingestion
  * Graph maintenance tasks
  * Periodic recalculations

### **Amazon CloudWatch**

* Centralized logging
* System monitoring
* Operational observability

## **Hybrid Execution Model**

### **AWS Lambda Handles:**

* Fast-path domain checks
* Cache lookups
* Lightweight scoring
* Immediate blocking decisions

### **ECS Fargate Handles:**

* NLP inference
* GNN embedding computation
* Campaign detection
* Infrastructure enrichment
* Graph recalculation

This separation ensures:

* Low latency for most requests
* Scalable compute for deep analysis
* Efficient resource utilization

## **Real-Time Prevention Loop**

1. The user loads a webpage.
2. Browser extension extracts forensic signals.
3. API Gateway forwards requests through WAF.
4. Lambda performs cache lookup and heuristic checks.
5. If high risk → immediate block (\<300ms).
6. If deeper analysis required → request queued in SQS.
7. ECS Fargate performs NLP + GNN processing.
8. Deterministic risk engine aggregates signals.
9. Results stored in RDS.
10. SOC dashboard updated.
11. Credential submission blocked if threshold exceeded.

## **Cost-Aware Design**

PhishGuard was built for efficiency:

* Lambda eliminates idle server costs.
* ECS runs only for deep scans.
* Redis caching reduces repeated ML computation.
* SQS prevents compute over-provisioning.
* Auto-scaling ensures infrastructure expands only under load.
* The majority of scans are resolved through cache or lightweight checks.

## **DEMO**

No Black Boxes — Just Visible, Verified Defense - https://youtu.be/fFLnZul\_seE

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIMdRxVEOrCfpsa0O34nCbphOF/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x581" caption="The browser extension performs live signal extraction and combines fast-path domain intelligence with backend graph analysis to generate deterministic risk scores and prevent high-risk credential harvesting attempts." />

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIMh4pUT3EydLRlQKsnSf8e7hp/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x581" caption="PhishGuard not only blocks threats but also validates legitimate platforms through structured signal analysis, ensuring precision without unnecessary disruption." />

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIMkWRPk01muMKyGEwqULgu1yl/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x513" caption="The PhishGuard SOC dashboard provides real-time visibility into active scans, blocked threats, campaign trends, and infrastructure intelligence, enabling proactive security monitoring at scale." />

## **What We Learned**

Building PhishGuard was not just about creating a phishing detection model — it was about designing a complete, scalable security system that balances latency, intelligence, cost, and explainability.

Through implementation, testing, and evaluation, I gained several critical insights:

### **1) Real-Time Prevention Requires Architectural Discipline**

Achieving **sub-second fast-path latency (\<300ms)** was only possible because of:

* Redis caching for repeated lookups
* AWS Lambda for lightweight scoring
* Separation of fast-path and deep-path logic

I learned that performance is not just about optimizing models — it is about structuring the system correctly.

### **2)Asynchronous Deep Analysis Is Essential**

Deep infrastructure analysis (GNN similarity, enrichment, clustering) averaged:

* **2.5–3.5 seconds** on ECS Fargate

Instead of blocking the user while heavy analysis runs, asynchronous processing ensures:

* Immediate protection
* Scalable intelligence updates
* Better resource utilization

This reinforced the importance of decoupling latency-sensitive components from compute-intensive workloads.

### **3) Infrastructure Signals Are Powerful**

Functional validation showed that:

* Newly registered domains contributed meaningfully to elevated risk scores
* Infrastructure similarity detection identified structurally related domains
* Campaign clustering provided contextual enrichment

This confirmed that phishing detection becomes stronger when moving beyond surface-level URL inspection to infrastructure correlation.

### **4)Explainability Builds Trust**

The structured explanation engine ensured:

* Risk outputs matched triggered findings
* No fabricated reasoning was generated
* Confidence values reflected signal consistency

I learned that in security systems, transparency is not optional — it is foundational.

### **5) Hybrid AI + Deterministic Logic Is More Stable**

The prototype used:

* **TF-IDF + Logistic Regression** for content analysis
* **128-dimensional GNN embeddings** for infrastructure similarity

But instead of relying solely on probabilistic outputs, deterministic aggregation:

* Prevented under-classification
* Enabled bounded scoring
* Allowed escalation safeguards

This hybrid approach provided more control and auditability than a pure black-box model.

### **6) Scalability and Cost Awareness Matter**

Prototype testing showed:

* Cache hit rate: ~60–70% under repeated domain scenarios
* Majority of scans resolved without deep compute

This demonstrated that:

* Redis caching significantly reduces ML invocation
* Lambda’s pay-per-use model prevents idle cost
* ECS should be triggered only when necessary

Designing for cost-efficiency is as important as designing for intelligence.

### **7) Limitations Expose Growth Areas**

The system currently has constraints:

* Reduced effectiveness against fully isolated, single-use infrastructure
* Dependence on external threat intelligence feeds
* Browser support limited to current implementation

These limitations clarified where future innovation is needed.

### **8)Future Improvements**

Based on evaluation, the next logical steps include:

* Cross-browser support expansion
* Automated retraining pipelines for NLP and GNN models
* Broader intelligence source integration
* Large-scale benchmarking for measurable detection accuracy
* Production-grade performance validation

## **Final Reflection**

PhishGuard demonstrates that infrastructure-aware, explainable phishing prevention is feasible within a deterministic, cloud-native architecture.

By integrating:

* Browser forensic signal extraction
* NLP-based content intelligence
* Graph-based infrastructure correlation
* Mathematically defined risk aggregation
* Event-driven AWS orchestration

The system shifts phishing defense from reactive blacklist dependency to proactive, infrastructure-level prevention.

The most important lesson we learned is this:

Building AI systems is not just about training better models.It is about engineering resilient, scalable systems where intelligence, performance, cost, and explainability coexist.

That balance is what makes real-world security solutions viable.
title: AIdeas : PhishGuard Nexus Unified Risk Intelligence Platform

author.bio: I am an aspiring DevOps, Cloud, and Systems Engineer with a strong foundation in Cyber Security and a passion for building scalable, secure, and automated cloud solutions using Amazon Web Services.

article.description:
Every year, thousands of Indian mothers die not because medicine failed them — but because the right information never reached the right person in time. MaatriSahayak fixes that with AI that thinks in Hindi, predicts danger before it peaks, and coordinates a full emergency response 
in under 60 seconds.

markdownDescription:
<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI3VQPOjwEw8WqCibI8t6UNfKQ/Whats.webp?imgSize=1000x558" />

**In a tribal village in rural Madhya Pradesh at 6 AM, a young woman arose with chest discomfort, blurry eyesight, and significant swelling in her legs. Her spouse dialed 108 without delay.She arrived at a Community Health Centre at 10 AM four hours afterward. No delivery doctor. A saltwater infusion. A recommendation. At the District Hospital, she remained for an additional two and a half hours before being sent again to a tertiary institution in Jabalpur.She passed away in the car during the journey.The condition: postpartum eclampsia. The remedy: magnesium sulfate. Price: ₹50. Time for administration: three minutes.In the published case record, she was identified only by a case number, lacking a name. Yet she belonged to someone as a wife, a daughter, a mother who never returned. This death is recorded in the Journal of Family Medicine and Primary Care, 2024.She did not die because no one tried. She died because every person who tried had nothing to work with.**

[https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11668477](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11668477/)

**MaatriSahayak was created to ensure this never occurs again.**

***

## **App Category**

**Social Impact**

## **What Is MaatriSahayak?**

* MaatriSahayak is an AI-powered maternal emergency platform that puts clinical intelligence directly into the hands of India's 1 million ASHA workers  the frontline community health volunteers who are often a pregnant woman's only point of contact with the healthcare system.
* It does three things no existing system does together:
* It **predicts** which pregnancies are heading toward a crisis before the crisis arrives  using a continuously running AI risk model, not a weekly paper form.
* It **understands** symptoms described in informal Hindi not structured English dropdown menus  and maps them instantly to clinical conditions using Amazon Bedrock.
* It **coordinates** the entire emergency response in parallel the moment a worker hits a button ambulance dispatch, hospital preparation, family notification, and authority alerts  in under 60 seconds, with zero phone calls.

**Description:** MaatriSahayak gives ASHA workers an AI risk engine, a one-tap emergency trigger, and a fully automated multi-stakeholder response system cutting emergency response time from 134 minutes to under 30 minutes using Amazon Bedrock, AWS Step Functions, SageMaker, and IoT Core.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI4G9gAWbWMSpe1mtLHYP6XbDp/Whats.webp?imgSize=521x413" />

***

## ***The Crisis Nobody Talks About Loudly Enough***

* India's maternal mortality numbers are quietly catastrophic in rural areas  and they stay quiet because the women dying are poor, rural, and far from anyone with a platform.
* **93** maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in rural India. Three times the urban rate.
* **134 minutes** the average time between a rural woman calling for help and an ambulance arriving. The clinical survival window for most obstetric emergencies is 30 minutes.
* **70%** of rural health center positions are unfilled. ASHA workers — often with minimal clinical training  are the only healthcare presence in thousands of villages.
* These three numbers are not independent. They are the same problem seen from three different angles. And the problem is not medicine. India has the doctors, the drugs, and the protocols to prevent most of these deaths.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI4pou2lJe5ZodvnkpAf673H6K/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x558" />

## **The problem is that the right information never reaches the right person in time**

* The ASHA worker does not know her patient's trajectory is dangerous  because the data lives on paper and no one is watching it. The ambulance does not know which hospital has a bed because no system tracks it. The hospital does not know the patient is coming because no one called ahead. And when they finally do call, the call does not connect.
* This is not a medical crisis. It is a **coordination and intelligence gap** and it kills thousands of women every year in a country that has everything needed to save them.

## **The Three Delays That Turn Survivable Into Fatal**

Researchers studying maternal mortality across low-income settings identified a pattern so consistent they named it: **The Three Delays Model.**

* **Delay One  Recognition:** The family does not know the symptom is serious. The ASHA worker does not have a tool to assess whether it is. Time passes.
* **Delay Two  Reaching Care:** The ambulance takes too long. The route is wrong. The hospital is full. No one coordinated any of it. More time passes.
* **Delay Three  Receiving Care:** The patient arrives at a facility that was not prepared. The doctor opens the chart cold. Treatment starts from zero. The remaining time runs out.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI58NNbMyfcORSqQg6BnBXMm8O/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x558" />

Each delay compounds the next. In the Madhya Pradesh case above, all three happened in sequence  and she never made it to the hospital that could have saved her.

**MaatriSahayak** was designed specifically to break all three delays simultaneously.

***

## ***How It Works: The Full Picture***

* An ASHA worker photographs a patient's handwritten ANC card. Amazon Textract reads it and builds a digital health record in seconds. From that moment, a continuously running AI model monitors that pregnancy  updating a live risk score every time a vital is logged, a symptom is mentioned, or a follow-up visit is recorded.
* The model does not wait for the ASHA to flag something. It watches the data between visits and raises the alarm when it detects a pattern heading toward danger days before a crisis becomes visible.
* When an emergency does strike, the ASHA worker describes the symptoms in her own words, in Hindi, exactly as the patient described them. Amazon Bedrock parses that natural language, identifies the clinical signals, classifies severity, and returns a plain-language action recommendation  in Hindi  in under two seconds.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI5VXBFYGb82hFz3fYzMVZRogW/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x528" />

* If the situation is critical, one tap on the emergency button fires everything at once through AWS Step Functions: the nearest ambulance is dispatched with the patient's complete history pre-loaded, the receiving hospital reserves a bed and receives the risk profile, the patient's family gets an SMS with a live ETA, and the district health officer is alerted on their dashboard all simultaneously, all automatically, in under 60 seconds.
* The ambulance driver's GPS is tracked in real time via AWS IoT Core. Every stakeholder  the ASHA worker, the ANM supervisor, the hospital team, the family sees the same live location on the same map. No one is left guessing.
* After the emergency resolves, the outcome is written back into the patient's longitudinal record. The next ASHA visit does not start from a blank form. It starts from a full picture of everything that has happened and whether the situation is improving or quietly getting worse.

***

## ***The Key Components***

### **① The Risk Engine: Watching What Paper Cannot See**

India has roughly one ASHA worker for every 1,000 people in rural areas. She visits each registered pregnant woman roughly once a week. Between those visits five, six, seven days  she has no visibility into what is happening.

That gap is where women die.

The **MaatriSahayak risk** engine runs continuously inside that gap. It is an ensemble model — XGBoost and Random Forest combined trained on over 100,000 historical pregnancies across 25+ clinical and demographic variables: blood pressure trend direction (not just the value), hemoglobin levels relative to gestational week, prior complication history, socioeconomic proximity to emergency care, ANC visit compliance.

**The model's core clinical insight: danger is a direction, not a number.**

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI5wbPgcSGC0aaJUAdgCPqq4mq/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x542" />

A blood pressure of 140/90 on a Tuesday could mean nothing. The same reading arrived on Thursday, climbing from 132/88 on Monday, alongside a reported complaint of leg swelling  that is a trajectory that precedes eclampsia. The model catches the direction. The weekly paper record shows only the individual moment.

**Validated performance:**

* **92% recall** nearly every high-risk pregnancy flagged before it peaks into crisis
* **87% precision** alerts carry weight, not alarm fatigue
* **\< 1 second** inference on AWS Lambda
* **Four tiers**: Low · Medium · High · Critical (86–100)

When Critical is reached, every relevant person is notified immediately and automatically.

### **② Bedrock Symptom Analysis: Built for the Person Actually Using It**

Here is the assumption buried inside almost every AI health tool deployed in rural India: that the user speaks medical English, fills structured forms, and selects symptoms from dropdown lists.

That assumption describes almost nobody working as an ASHA worker in a village in **Uttar Pradesh or Jharkhand**.

MaatriSahayak was designed from the opposite direction. The ASHA worker inputs what the patient told her  in whatever words came out, in whatever dialect, however incomplete. She does not need to know what eclampsia is. She just needs to be able to say what the patient said.

**Amazon Bedrock** receives that sentence and simultaneously runs four operations: language register identification, embedded clinical signal extraction, obstetric condition mapping, and severity classification. The output arrives in under two seconds, in Hindi, with a plain-language recommended action.

***"पेट में बहुत दर्द है, उल्टी हो रही है, आँखों के आगे अँधेरा आ रहा है"***

```json
{
  "symptoms": ["severe_abdominal_pain", "vomiting", "visual_disturbance"],
  "possible_conditions": ["preeclampsia", "placental_abruption"],
  "severity": "CRITICAL",
  "recommended_action": "EMERGENCY_REFERRAL",
  "plain_language_guidance": "यह बहुत गंभीर है। तुरंत एम्बुलेंस बुलाएं।"
}
```

The system prompt behind Bedrock is not a general-purpose medical assistant instruction. It is a structured clinical protocol grounded in WHO maternal emergency guidelines, National Health Mission ASHA protocols, and the specific obstetric vocabulary of the conditions that kill Indian mothers most  preeclampsia grading scales, placental abruption warning signs, postpartum hemorrhage thresholds, puerperal sepsis indicators.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI6UMhRgJyywPod4cPvd2TKpti/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x529" />

We tested the same model on the same 200 emergency cases with two different prompts  generic medical and domain-grounded obstetric. Emergency classification accuracy went from 44% to 91%.

**The model did not change. The compute did not change. The clinical vocabulary in the prompt changed everything.**

### **③ Step Functions Orchestration: Replacing the Phone Call Chain**

This is what a real rural maternal emergency response looks like in India today:

The ASHA calls the ANM. The ANM calls the PHC. The PHC staff try to find the 108 number. The dispatcher asks for a street address. The address does not exist in any database. The driver calls back. A family member tries to call the district hospital. The line is busy. The patient is loaded into a private vehicle. She arrives at a facility that has no idea she is coming. The on-call physician opens her chart for the first time in the emergency bay.

Total coordination failures in that chain: at least seven. Total time lost: often more than an hour.

MaatriSahayak does not try to fix that chain. It removes it.

When the ASHA worker taps the emergency button, AWS Step Functions triggers three parallel execution branches simultaneously no phone calls, no human bottleneck, no sequential waiting.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI75weWhEBHgnNzGtT8BQKRXQX/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x536" />

**Branch A  Ambulance Dispatch:** Lambda queries DynamoDB for real-time ambulance availability, calculates distances via Amazon Location Service, selects the nearest vehicle, pre-loads the complete patient history and GPS pin to the driver's device, and starts navigation — before the driver confirms the alert.

**Branch B Hospital Readiness:** Lambda identifies the best-fit receiving hospital, reserves a maternity bed, and pushes the patient's full risk profile, vital trend history, suspected diagnosis, and recommended treatment protocol to the hospital team. They are preparing before the ambulance has moved.

**Branch C Stakeholder Notification:** SNS sends a live ETA to the patient's family. The district health officer's dashboard updates in real time. The ANM supervisor receives a push notification. Amazon Connect fires a voice call to the driver as a redundant confirmation layer.

Every branch runs simultaneously. The total elapsed time from button tap to ambulance moving, hospital prepared, and family informed: **under 60 seconds.**

Not a faster version of the broken system. A different system entirely.

### **④ The Living Record: Every Visit Builds on the Last**

Paper-based maternal health records have a fundamental flaw that no amount of better paper can fix: they exist in one place, they get lost, and they tell you nothing about what happened between the last visit and this one.

When an ASHA worker opens MaatriSahayak for a follow-up visit, she does not start from a blank form. She sees a complete longitudinal picture: the risk score at 20 weeks, the vitals trend at 28 weeks, what triggered the alert at 32 weeks, what the emergency response looked like, and whether the current status is improving, stable, or quietly deteriorating.

Every emergency and every routine visit writes a structured record to DynamoDB, indexed by patient ID and GPS-verified location. That record grows more complete with every interaction.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI9D9WYP2Xw443eexWdmLIGZIb/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x553" />

For district health officers, the aggregate of those records creates something that has never existed before in most of rural India: a real-time, GPS-verified maternal risk map showing exactly which villages have the highest concentration of high-risk pregnancies right now, which ambulances are underutilized, and which hospitals are approaching capacity — before any of those situations become emergencies.

**The system does not just respond to crises. It builds the institutional memory needed to prevent them.**

***

## ***How I Built This***

### **System Architecture**

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI9KPrxftijAnuK6Ec53x3Xo7H/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x691" />

```plaintext
ASHA Worker — React Native Android App — Offline First
              ↓
AWS Amplify → API Gateway → Lambda: Validate & Route
              ↓
Amazon Textract: ANC Card OCR → DynamoDB Patient Record
              ↓
SageMaker Endpoint: Risk Model Inference — XGBoost + RF
              ↓
Amazon Bedrock Nova: Hindi Symptom Analysis
              ↓
      CRITICAL THRESHOLD CROSSED
              ↓
AWS Step Functions: Emergency Workflow — 3 Parallel Branches
       ↓                    ↓                      ↓
Ambulance Dispatch    Hospital Bed          SNS Family SMS + ANM Push + Connect
 via Location Svc     Reserved + Risk Sent              
              ↓
AWS IoT Core: Real-Time GPS → Timestream → AppSync
              ↓
All Dashboards Updated Live — ASHA, ANM, Hospital, District Officer
              ↓
DynamoDB: Outcome Logged → Longitudinal Patient Record Updated
```

### **Building for the Right User First**

* Most health tech products are designed for the doctor, the hospital administrator, or the government official. MaatriSahayak was designed for the ASHA worker  a community health volunteer with basic literacy, a mid-range Android phone, intermittent 2G connectivity, and a caseload of 40+ pregnant women spread across multiple villages.
* Every feature that required assumptions about the user's environment  reliable internet, English literacy, medical vocabulary, consistent electricity  was cut or redesigned. What remained works in the actual conditions of rural India, not the imagined conditions of an urban planning office.
* Onboarding time for an ASHA worker: two hours of in-person training. The interface: icon-based, Hindi throughout, voice input for symptom description. The connectivity requirement: none for core functions. Everything syncs when the connection returns.

### **Offline-First App**

* The standard mobile development approach treats offline as an edge case. In rural Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, or Assam, offline is the default operating condition.
* MaatriSahayak stores all patient data locally in SQLite. Every write to the local database simultaneously queues a sync operation. Background synchronization resolves conflicts using field-level merging — meaning a vital recorded during a six-hour connectivity gap is never lost and never overwrites more recent data when it syncs.
* The emergency trigger works over SMS as a complete fallback. The backend parses the structured SMS and processes it identically to an API call. No internet required to save a life.

### **Why Step Functions Over Direct Lambda Chaining**

* The first version of the emergency workflow chained Lambda functions directly. When a function timed out, nothing happened  silently. The ambulance was not dispatched. No one knew.
* Step Functions made every state transition visible, every failure explicit and retryable, and every branch independently testable and deployable. The execution graph in the AWS console became the most valuable debugging tool in the entire system.
* In a system where a silent failure means an ambulance does not move, observability is not a nice-to-have. It is a clinical requirement.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIAE8fDXjATvsWthUjZt3pjrTn/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x521" />

### **Textract and the Human Review Queue**

* Amazon Textract extracts data from handwritten ANC cards with 92% accuracy on legible handwriting. For confidence scores below 85%, MaatriSahayak does not write the extraction to the patient record  it routes it to the ANM supervisor's review queue.
* This was a deliberate design choice, not a fallback. In a medical record, a misread blood group or a wrong LMP date does not produce a data quality issue. It produces a wrong diagnosis. Knowing what the system does not know  and flagging it loudly  is as important as what the system does know.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIAN8Ai06OyZhJMAEQtlw4BXP7/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x505" />

***

## **How We Built This**

MaatriSahayak was built with an uncompromising focus on three constraints that could not be traded off against each other: it had to work offline, it had to work in Hindi, and it had to be fast enough to save a life.

Every architecture decision, every AWS service choice, and every UI screen was evaluated against all three simultaneously.

## **High-Level Architecture**

Our system is built using **Amazon Web Services (AWS)** and modern web/mobile technologies.

* **Mobile App (ASHA Worker App):**
  Built with React Native. It works fully offline using SQLite and syncs data when the internet is available. All features like vitals recording and emergency alerts work without network.
* **Web Dashboard:**
  Developed using React and TypeScript with charts for data visualization. Different users (ASHA, ANM, officers, hospitals) get access based on roles. It shows real-time updates.
* **Backend (Serverless):**
  Uses multiple AWS Lambda functions for user management, health records, emergencies, notifications, AI, and more. API Gateway and Cognito handle secure access.
* **Database:**
  DynamoDB stores patient data, risk scores, and emergency records. It is optimized for fast risk checking and ambulance search.
* **AI & Intelligence Layer:**
  * SageMaker runs ML models for pregnancy risk prediction.
  * Bedrock helps in medical reasoning based on official guidelines.
  * Textract reads ANC cards, and low-confidence data is verified by supervisors.
* **Emergency Management:**
  Step Functions controls emergency workflows. All steps are logged for tracking and reliability.
* **Ambulance & Location Tracking:**
  IoT Core tracks ambulance GPS. Location Service finds the nearest ambulance and hospital. Timestream stores route history.
* **Notifications:**
  SNS sends SMS and app alerts. Amazon Connect makes voice calls to ensure no emergency is missed.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIGh3ud3sb7nzwMVUzrB9ijGSh/Scre.webp?imgSize=922x860" />

**District Health Dashboard : Analytics**

* The analytics panel shows what has never been visible before in most rural districts: aggregate maternal health intelligence derived from ground-level data rather than monthly paper reports.
* Risk distribution across the district. ANC visit compliance rates by block. Average response time trend over the past 30 days. High-risk pregnancy concentration by village. Ambulance utilization rates. Hospital capacity trends. Outcome data for resolved emergencies.
* For the first time, a district health officer can see whether the system is working — and where it is not — from a live dashboard rather than waiting for a report that arrives weeks after the data was collected.

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIHNhqo02X5WKmAyVXbp8D9Bo2/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x480" shape="rounded" zoom="true" />

### **The Predictive Intelligence Loop**

* The technical core of MaatriSahayak is the continuous risk monitoring pipeline that runs between ASHA visits.
* When a worker logs vitals, the data writes to DynamoDB and simultaneously triggers a Lambda function that calls the SageMaker risk model. The model does not score the new reading in isolation  it scores it in the context of every previous reading for that patient, computing the trajectory across 25+ features.
* If the new score crosses a risk tier threshold, an SNS notification fires immediately to the ANM supervisor and is surfaced on the district dashboard. The ASHA worker receives a push notification on her next app open with a recommended action for the flagged patient.
* The worker does not have to notice the change. The system already has. The loop runs silently between every visit watching the trajectories that paper forms cannot see, waiting for the pattern that precedes the crisis, and acting before the crisis arrives.

***

## ***AWS Services and Their Roles***

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIBQouhcBl4PV6qL7K93BpYs6J/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x554" />

### **Five Things Building This Taught Me**

1. **The User Is Not Who You Think They Are**

* Early prototypes were tested internally  by developers with medical knowledge, reliable internet, and English fluency. They worked fine. The first field test with actual ASHA workers revealed that almost every assumption about how the app would be used was wrong.
* Voice input replaced text entry for most symptom recording. Icon navigation replaced menu navigation. Hindi replaced every English label. The emergency button moved from a menu item to the home screen's most prominent element.

**Build with the actual user from week one. Not a proxy.**

1. **Silence Is the Worst Failure Mode**

* In consumer software, a silent failure means a user sees an error screen. In an emergency response system, a silent failure means an ambulance is not dispatched and nobody knows why.
* Every failure in MaatriSahayak is loud, logged, retried, and escalated. Step Functions makes state transitions explicit. CloudWatch alarms on every Lambda error. Dead-letter queues catch every failed SNS message. The system is designed to fail noisily and recover automatically because a quiet failure here has consequences that cannot be undone.

1. **Confidence Scores Are Not Optional in Medical AI**

* The first instinct in AI system design is to automate everything and trust the model. In a maternal health system, that instinct is dangerous.
* The model is right 92% of the time on recall. That means some fraction of high-risk cases are missed, and some low-risk classifications are wrong. For a wellness app, that is acceptable. For a system that determines whether a woman receives emergency care, it requires a human review layer at the right confidence thresholds.

**Know your model's failure rate. Design the system around it, not away from it.**

1. **The 60-Second Target Shaped Every Architecture Decision**

* From the beginning, one number drove every design choice: under 60 seconds from emergency button tap to ambulance moving, hospital prepared, family notified. Every architectural decision was measured against that target.
* Direct Lambda chaining added 8 seconds of overhead compared to Step Functions parallel execution. Synchronous hospital bed queries added 12 seconds — replaced with an async reservation queue. Each optimization was measured, not estimated.

Current median: **47 seconds.** Target: 30. The work continues.

1. **Designing for No Internet Surfaced Better Ideas**

* The offline-first constraint forced every feature into a simpler, more robust form. Features that required real-time server state were redesigned to work on cached local data with background sync. Features that could not survive intermittent connectivity were removed entirely.
* The result is a system that is more reliable in a connected environment than a connected-first design would have been — because every component was stress-tested against the hardest operating conditions from the start.

***

## **The Before and After**

|                   What Was True                   |                  What MaatriSahayak Changes                 |
| :-----------------------------------------------: | :---------------------------------------------------------: |
|   Risk visible only when symptoms become severe   | Continuous AI monitoring flags trajectory danger days early |
|      Ambulance response: 134 minutes average      |             Targeted dispatch: under 30 minutes             |
|     Hospital receives patient with zero notice    |    Full risk profile delivered 20+ minutes before arrival   |
|   ASHA worker assesses risk from intuition alone  |      Real-time AI scoring across 25+ clinical variables     |
| Emergency coordination: 7+ sequential phone calls |        Parallel automated response: under 60 seconds        |
|  Patient record: paper, often lost or incomplete  |      Longitudinal digital record, GPS-keyed, permanent      |

**At national scale:**

* 5,000+ maternal lives saved annually
* 100,000+ ASHA workers with clinical AI support
* First real-time maternal risk registry for rural India
* 77% reduction in average emergency response time

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AIEWJlWyVJJqqm1bn0Rz1NxS8z/Gemi.webp?imgSize=1000x558" />

***

## Built By

**TEAM ARAK CREW**
Team Members: @krux2dev9, @arpituttam, @rishitiwari023, @aps36

***

> **"Somewhere in rural India right now, an ASHA worker is visiting a pregnant woman with a paper form and nothing else. MaatriSahayak is what she should have instead."**
title: AIdeas: MaatriSahayak —When a Mother's Life Depends on a 60-Second Window

article.description:
Turn raw AWS logs into audit-ready “evidence packs” and incident timelines, without shipping a single byte out of your account.
App category: Commercial Solutions  #aideas-2025, #commercial-solutions, #APJC

markdownDescription:
## **App category**

#### Commercial Solutions  `#aideas-2025`*,* `#commercial-solutions`*,* `#APJC`

***

#### My vision

Most security teams don’t struggle with a lack of data.
They drown in it.

VPC Flow Logs know exactly which workloads talked to which subnets. CloudTrail knows who changed which security group and when. Athena can query all of it directly in S3.

But when an auditor asks:

> “Show me evidence that this workload didn’t talk to the internet last quarter.”

or when an engineer asks:

> “Who talked to this database right before the incident?”

you still see people screenshotting consoles, exporting CSVs, and gluing everything together in spreadsheets.

**NetProbe Lite** is my attempt to fix that for AWS-first teams.

My vision is simple:

* Take **two raw streams** you already have:  **VPC Flow Logs** and **CloudTrail**.
* Turn them into curated, **downloadable “Evidence Packs”** and **clickable incident timelines** for specific:
  * time windows,
  * workloads (tags / security groups),
  * or subnets / accounts.
* Keep everything inside **your AWS account**, powered by **Athena, S3, Lambda, and optional Bedrock** for narrative summaries.

So instead of “Give me a week to pull the logs and build a deck,” a security engineer can say:

> “Here’s your NetProbe pack: report + raw queries + timeline. Sample anything you want.”

NetProbe Lite is intentionally **small and opinionated**: one AWS account, one evidence use case, minimal UI but a very strong promise:

> If the logs exist in S3, you can turn them into a reusable evidence bundle in minutes, not days.

***

## Why this matters

### The reality for small security teams

If you’re a SaaS / fintech / healthtech team on AWS with a small security function, you probably recognise this pattern:

* **Audits**: PCI / SOC 2 asks:
  * “Show network segmentation between these components.”
  * “Show samples of denied traffic.”
* **Incidents**: Someone pushes a risky security group, or a workload starts talking to a forbidden IP range.
* **Your reality**:
  * Dig through VPC Flow Logs.
  * Dig through CloudTrail for security group / NACL / route / IAM changes.
  * Hand-craft a narrative with screenshots + CSV snippets.

AWS **recommends enabling flow logs and CloudTrail** for continuous visibility and compliance, because they provide clear audit trails and support regulatory standards.
But having the data is not the same as having **evidence**.

Evidence has structure:

* A **time-boxed scope** (“this week, this subnet, this SG”).
* A **repeatable query set** (allowed/denied flows, unusual ports, before/after changes).
* A **bundle** you can:
  * download,
  * hand to an auditor,
  * or attach to an incident ticket.

Right now, most teams reinvent those queries and screenshots every time.

### Why it fits the “Commercial Solutions” category

For commercial, regulated SaaS products, time is money:

* Every **manual audit prep** cycle steals engineering hours.
* Every **slow incident investigation** increases MTTR and customer risk.
* Every extra tool that requires **shipping logs to a third-party SIEM** adds cost and privacy/compliance risk.

NetProbe Lite matters because it:

* **Reuses what you already pay for** (VPC Flow Logs, CloudTrail, S3, Athena).
* Stays inside **your AWS account** (BYO data lake).
* Produces **consistent, re-checkable evidence,** not just pretty dashboards.
* Can grow into a full **NetProbe platform** later (ClickHouse, richer agents), but already creates value as a small, focused tool.

***

## How I built this

### High-level architecture

At a high level, NetProbe Lite is:

> “An evidence compiler on top of S3 + Athena, with a thin web UI and optional AI narration.”

Core pieces:

1. **Log sources → S3**
   * **VPC Flow Logs** deliver connection metadata (source/dest, ports, action, bytes) to S3.
   * **CloudTrail** delivers API and configuration change events (who changed what, and when) to S3.
2. **Athena data model**
   * External tables for:
     * `vpc_flow_logs_raw`
     * `cloudtrail_events_raw`
   * A small **“pack scope” table** (or DynamoDB) mapping:
     * pack\_id → time window, AWS account, VPC, subnet, tags / SG filters.
3. **Evidence Pack Builder (Lambda)**
   * Given a `pack_id` and filters, the Lambda:
     1. Runs a **library of Athena queries**:
        * Allowed / denied flows in scope.
        * Top talkers by bytes/packets.
        * Flows crossing sensitive boundaries (e.g., “prod DB SG” ↔ “internet-facing”).
        * Change events in the same window (SG / NACL / route / IAM changes).
     2. Writes query outputs as **CSV / JSON** to a dedicated S3 prefix.
     3. Renders a **static HTML report** using a templating engine.
     4. Optionally calls **Amazon Bedrock** with the query outputs to generate a **grounded narrative** where every paragraph cites specific query sections.
4. **Static UI (S3 website or CloudFront)**
   * Simple React / static UI deployed to S3:
     * “Create new pack” wizard (time window + scope).
     * List of generated packs with status.
     * View/download HTML report and raw CSVs.
5. **Optional: Guardrails**
   * Simple heuristics to keep everything **within Free Tier / credit limits**:
     * Limit time window (e.g., default 1–7 days).
     * Restrict scope (single VPC / subnet / SG).
     * Show an estimate of **bytes scanned + cost** before running heavy packs using Athena’s pricing model.

***

### Build phases & technical milestones

I thought of the build in **four phases**.

#### Phase 1: Make the logs queryable

* Enable **VPC Flow Logs to S3** and **CloudTrail to S3** with partitioned prefixes (by day / account / region).
* Create Athena external tables with sensible partition keys (`year`, `month`, `day`, `aws_region`).
* Sanity-check queries:
  * “Show me all denied flows for this SG over 24h.”
  * “Show me all `AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress` calls in the same period.”

Goal: prove that **the raw data you need already exists** and can be queried cheaply.

#### Phase 2: Design the evidence pack schema

Instead of “run whatever queries”, I designed a **fixed schema** for an Evidence Pack:

* **Header**
  * `pack_id`, time window, scope filters, generation timestamp, AWS account.
* **Sections**
  * Segmentation overview (flows between key SGs/subnets).
  * Allowed / denied flows by priority.
  * Unusual ports / protocols.
  * Change timeline:
    * SG / NACL / route table changes.
    * IAM changes relevant to networking.
* **Artifacts**
  * CSV/JSON for each section.
  * HTML view that links charts → underlying tables.

This step matters because it turns NetProbe Lite into a **product**, not just a directory of saved Athena queries.

#### Phase 3: Automate pack generation

* Implement a **Lambda-based Pack Builder**:
  * Triggered by:
    * a button in UI, or
    * an EventBridge schedule (e.g., daily/weekly packs).
  * Orchestrates 8–12 Athena queries in sequence.
  * Writes outputs into `s3://…/netprobe-lite/packs/{pack_id}/…`.
* Generate the **HTML report**:
  * Simple, auditor-friendly layout:
    * Executive summary.
    * High-risk findings (e.g., unexpected egress, blocked attempts).
    * Timeline of “who changed what before/after unusual flows.”
* Expose pack status in UI:
  * `pending → running → completed / failed`
  * Basic retry and error logging.

#### Phase 4: Optional AI narrative with Amazon Bedrock

I treat AI as **a narrator, not a detector**:

* Bedrock receives:
  * Selected aggregates (JSON),
  * Top N rows from key queries,
  * Clear instructions: “Summarize these tables; cite query names; don’t invent facts.”()
* It returns:
  * A short, auditor-friendly narrative like:> “During 2025-11-01 to 2025-11-07, workload `payments-api` had 3,421 allowed outbound connections and 0 denied attempts to the public internet. All database access originated from two expected security groups. See ‘segmentation\_summary’ for raw samples.”
* Every sentence is linked back to a specific query output, so if the AI summary is ever questioned, an auditor can **drill down to the raw data instantly**.

***

###

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI7mTwtViZTh5in6yYdZuJxa5J/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x562" shape="rounded" />

### Evidence Packs dashboard

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI8Ty96ZBakBw8XqbWvoivSYh3/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x502" caption="NetProbe Lite home view showing a list of generated Evidence Packs, each scoped to a specific VPC / security group and time window." shape="rounded" />

### Pack detail + segmentation summary

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI8gXA8DfURWD7AE38CnwC8vWC/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x505" caption="Pack overview for a payments-api workload, with cards for segmentation health, denied flows, and recent configuration changes" shape="rounded" />

### Change timeline view

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI9TCXEWl0VyJzafAqebdLXp7m/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x503" caption="Time-ordered correlation of unusual flows with CloudTrail events such as security group edits and IAM policy updates." shape="rounded" />

<Image url="https://prod-assets.cosmic.aws.dev/a/3AI9cKJYeMEjAanJUQPp6daVll8/Scre.webp?imgSize=1000x504" />

***

## What I learned

### 1. Evidence is a **data-contract problem**, not a dashboard problem

The hardest part wasn’t the UI, it was **deciding what a “good” pack always contains**:

* Which queries are mandatory?
* What’s the minimum set of tables an auditor needs to re-run?
* How do we make every visual traceable back to a raw dataset?

Once I treated packs like **APIs with schemas** (“this report always contains X, Y, Z artifacts”), everything else snapped into place.

### 2. AWS-native building blocks go a long way

I originally assumed I’d need a heavy external SIEM or data warehouse, but:

* **VPC Flow Logs to S3 + Athena** already give you scalable, queryable flow data.
* **CloudTrail to S3** already gives you a full history of changes.
* A little bit of glue (Lambda, DynamoDB) was enough to compile them into packs.

The bigger lesson: before adding new infrastructure, **exploit your cloud’s native logging and analytics features** as far as they can go.

### 3. “Audit-friendly” UX is its own design discipline

Security engineers think in queries and logs. Auditors think in **samples, periods, and controls**.

Designing NetProbe Lite forced me to:

* Name packs by **scope + period** (“payments-api / prod / last 7 days”).
* Make it obvious which **controls** a pack supports (e.g., “egress control,” “segmentation evidence”).
* Always let auditors **download raw CSV/JSON** to re-check conclusions.

It’s a different mental model from “pretty dashboard for internal engineers.”

### 4. AI should compress, not improvise

Working through the Bedrock integration made one thing very clear:

* Ungrounded AI summaries are **dangerous** in an audit context.
* Grounded AI summaries with explicit citations to Athena results are **incredibly useful**.

The key insight: AI is most valuable here as a **compression engine** turning dense query outputs into a short narrative **without ever inventing new facts**.

### 5. Guardrails matter as much as features

Because this is meant to run within AWS Free Tier / credits where possible, I had to treat **cost as a first-class constraint**:

* Narrow default scope and time windows.
* Show estimated bytes scanned before launching large packs.
* Design packs as **repeatable units** you can schedule, not ad-hoc giant queries.

That constraint forced cleaner SQL, better partitioning, and a leaner product.
title: AIdeas: NetProbe Lite - Network Evidence Packs for AWS
