article.description: In today’s data-driven enterprises, unstructured documents like PDFs contain valuable knowledge that often remains untapped. By combining AWS services with Databricks endpoints, organizations can automatically extract information, generate semantic triples, and construct scalable knowledge graphs.

markdownDescription:
1. PDF Ingestion & Text Extraction (AWS)

The pipeline begins by storing PDFs in Amazon S3, which acts as the centralized data lake. When a document is uploaded, an AWS Lambda function is triggered to orchestrate processing.

For text extraction:
•	Amazon Textract extracts structured content (forms, tables, paragraphs).
•	If documents are complex or scanned, Textract’s OCR capabilities ensure accurate text retrieval.

The extracted text is stored back in S3 or indexed in Amazon OpenSearch for searchability.

1. Entity & Relationship Extraction

Next, we process the extracted text using:
•	Amazon Comprehend for Named Entity Recognition (NER) to identify entities such as organizations, people, dates, and locations.
•	Custom ML models hosted via Amazon SageMaker (optional) for domain-specific extraction.

Alternatively, the cleaned text can be sent to a Databricks Model Serving Endpoint (e.g., LLM or fine-tuned transformer) for advanced relation extraction. The endpoint returns structured outputs in the form of semantic triples:

1. Semantic Triple Generation (Databricks)

Databricks enables scalable NLP pipelines using Spark. Using a deployed endpoint:
•	Apply prompt-based LLM extraction.
•	Convert unstructured text into RDF-style triples.
•	Normalize entities using embedding similarity (via MLflow-registered models).

This hybrid approach ensures high recall and contextual reasoning.

1. Knowledge Graph Construction

The generated triples are stored in:
•	Amazon Neptune (fully managed graph database) for RDF or property graph storage.
•	Alternatively, persist structured triples in S3 and process using Spark GraphFrames in Databricks.

1. Orchestration & Monitoring
   •	AWS Step Functions coordinate multi-stage workflows.
   •	CloudWatch monitors performance and logs.
   •	CI/CD pipelines integrate with MLflow for model lifecycle management.

⸻

Outcome:
This architecture transforms static PDFs into queryable knowledge graphs—enabling intelligent search, relationship discovery, compliance automation, and reasoning-driven decision support at enterprise scale.
title: Building Knowledge Graphs from PDFs Using AWS and Databricks

article.description: The moment AI becomes useful isn’t when it produces impressive text. It’s when it becomes predictable enough to behave like a system component.

markdownDescription:
There’s a moment when generative AI moves from interesting to useful. It usually happens the first time you integrate an LLM into a real system. Not a demo. Not a playground. An actual workflow with downstream dependencies.That’s when the problem appears. The model talks too much, too loosely, too creatively. Suddenly your architecture depends on parsing paragraphs.That’s where structured output changes everything.

## The problem most builders hit

When we first introduce AI into an application, the natural instinct is simple.

Call the model.
Get text.
Extract what we need.

It works. Until it doesn’t.

To explore this properly, consider a platform that processes unstructured input, evaluates it using AI, and produces structured signals that feed downstream workflows.

In that platform, AI isn’t decorative. It sits inside a workflow that turns unstructured input into structured signals the system can trust.

In other words, the AI is part of a pipeline. It is not the destination.

Free-form text becomes a liability.

* You end up writing brittle regex.
* You add defensive parsing.
* You introduce silent failures.

And worst of all, you lose trust in the result.

So the goal wasn’t “use AI”.

The goal was:

> Make AI behave like a component.

***

## Why “respond with JSON” isn’t enough

Most builders start by telling the model to return JSON.

It feels structured. It looks structured. It often works.

Until it doesn’t.

You’ll see:

* Missing fields
* Extra fields
* Invalid JSON
* Fields renamed subtly
* Narrative leaking into structured sections

That creates a new class of reliability work. AI repair logic.

Ironically, the more important the workflow becomes, the more defensive code you write around the AI.

Which is backwards.

The system shouldn’t adapt to the model.
The model should adapt to the system.

***

## The reliability problem behind “just return JSON”

There’s a deeper issue that most builders eventually discover.

LLMs don’t generate JSON.
They generate text that looks like JSON.

That distinction matters.

Even with careful prompting you will eventually see:

* Token truncation producing partial objects
* Valid JSON with missing required fields
* Subtle type drift (strings vs numbers)
* Extra properties the system didn’t ask for
* Structurally valid output that is semantically wrong
* Streaming responses cut mid-structure

None of these are unusual. They are a natural side effect of probabilistic generation.

Which means asking for JSON is not a reliability strategy.

It is a hope.

Production systems shouldn’t depend on hope.

***

## Enter Amazon Bedrock Structured Outputs

Amazon Bedrock’s structured output capability gives you a way to solve this properly.

Instead of asking the model to return JSON, you define a schema. Bedrock enforces that schema at generation time.

The shift is subtle but important.

You stop hoping the model follows instructions.
You give the model a contract.

That contract becomes architecture.

If the model cannot produce valid output, the call fails early. Production systems prefer predictable failure.

***

## Where it fits in the system

Inside the platform, structured output sits within an automated evaluation workflow.

At a high level:

1. Unstructured content is submitted via an upload or API
2. The backend extracts relevant text or signals
3. Bedrock evaluates the content against defined criteria
4. The result is persisted as a structured record

Before structured output, the evaluation step was fragile.

After structured output, it became deterministic.

The AI now returns a predictable object that the system can trust.

***

## Designing the schema (this is the real work)

The biggest learning wasn’t technical.

It was architectural.

A schema forces clarity.

You have to decide:

* What the system actually needs
* What the model should not invent
* Which fields drive decisions versus explanation
* Where uncertainty must be visible

In practice, the schema focuses on signals:

* Overall match score
* Criteria alignment breakdown
* Strengths
* Gaps
* Confidence
* Recommendation summary

The schema intentionally biases toward signals, not prose.

***

## Code sample 1: define a compact schema contract

This is a simplified schema that captures decision signals without turning the model into a report writer.

```json
{
  "type": "object",
  "additionalProperties": false,
  "properties": {
    "overall_score": { "type": "number", "minimum": 0, "maximum": 100 },
    "confidence": { "type": "number", "minimum": 0, "maximum": 1 },
    "strengths": { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string" } },
    "gaps": { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string" } },
    "recommendation": { "type": "string" }
  },
  "required": ["overall_score", "confidence", "strengths", "gaps"]
}
```

A couple of intentional choices:

* `additionalProperties: false` keeps the output tight and predictable.
* `required` is small. You can add fields later, but start with what the system truly needs.

***

## Code sample 2: invoke Bedrock with structured output

This example uses the Bedrock Runtime `converse` API. The important part is that the schema is sent as part of the request, and you treat the structured output as the primary payload.

```python
import boto3

bedrock = boto3.client("bedrock-runtime")

schema = {
    "type": "object",
    "additionalProperties": False,
    "properties": {
        "overall_score": {"type": "number", "minimum": 0, "maximum": 100},
        "confidence": {"type": "number", "minimum": 0, "maximum": 1},
        "strengths": {"type": "array", "items": {"type": "string"}},
        "gaps": {"type": "array", "items": {"type": "string"}},
        "recommendation": {"type": "string"},
    },
    "required": ["overall_score", "confidence", "strengths", "gaps"],
}

messages = [
    {
        "role": "user",
        "content": [
            {"text": "Evaluate the input against the criteria."},
            {"text": "Return ONLY structured output that matches the schema."},
            {"text": f"INPUT:\n{input_text}"},
            {"text": f"CRITERIA:\n{criteria_text}"},
        ],
    }
]

resp = bedrock.converse(
    modelId="YOUR_MODEL_ID",
    messages=messages,
    inferenceConfig={
        "temperature": 0,
        "maxTokens": 1200,
    },
    outputConfig={
        "structuredOutput": {
            "schema": schema
        }
    },
)

structured = resp["output"]["structuredOutput"]["data"]
print(structured["overall_score"], structured["confidence"])
```

Two practical notes:

* Keep `temperature` low for decision workflows.
* Keep your schema small so it is easy to satisfy and easy to test.

***

## Thoughtworks context: why this mattered internally

Within Thoughtworks, much of the platform work around delivery readiness, capability intelligence, and internal decision support depends on consistent signals rather than narrative interpretation.

Structured output allowed us to standardise how AI contributes to internal decision-making without introducing additional manual validation steps.

Instead of reviewing long AI summaries, teams can consume structured signals directly inside workflows. This reduces friction in essential procedures.

That shift is subtle, but operationally significant.

***

## Code sample 3: validate and version the contract

Structured output reduces drift, but you still want a clean contract boundary inside your own code. In practice that means validating the response and versioning the schema.

Here is a minimal validation pattern using Pydantic. It gives you a single place to enforce types and defaults.

```python
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field, conlist, confloat

class EvaluationV1(BaseModel):
    overall_score: confloat(ge=0, le=100)
    confidence: confloat(ge=0, le=1)
    strengths: conlist(str, min_length=1) = Field(default_factory=list)
    gaps: conlist(str, min_length=0) = Field(default_factory=list)
    recommendation: str | None = None

def parse_evaluation(payload: dict) -> EvaluationV1:
    return EvaluationV1.model_validate(payload)

# Example usage:
# evaluation = parse_evaluation(structured)
# store(evaluation.model_dump(), schema_version="v1")
```

This buys you two things:

* Your downstream code stays stable even if your prompts evolve.
* You can change the contract intentionally by introducing `EvaluationV2`.

***

## Why this matters beyond AI

Structured output creates a boundary.

It turns AI from a conversation into a service dependency.

Once that boundary exists:

* Validation shifts left
* Persistence becomes straightforward
* Observability improves
* Testing becomes possible

You can now write tests against the shape of AI output.

That is a meaningful step toward production readiness.

***

## Practical lessons learned

Smaller schemas work better.
Separate signals from explanation.
Confidence changes automation.
Treat schema as versioned contract.
Failure modes improve.

***

## What changed in the platform

Introducing structured output didn’t add complexity.

It removed it.

The workflow became:

* more predictable
* easier to debug
* safer to evolve
* easier to test
* cheaper to maintain

AI began to feel less magical and more like infrastructure.

***

## Zooming out

We are moving from prompt engineering toward interface design. The question is no longer what you should ask the model. The question is what contract should exist between the model and the system. Structured output makes that explicit and nudges architects to design AI the same way we design APIs.

In early AI integrations, the hardest part is not calling the model. It is trusting the result. Structured output helps earn that trust, not because it makes the model smarter, but because it makes the system clearer. And clarity scales. For builders, that is the real value.
title: Teaching AI to Behave: Structured Output with Amazon Bedrock in Production

markdownDescription:

⸻

1. Product Overview

Pawfect Match is an AI-driven dating platform built exclusively for pet lovers. The system enables:
•	User and pet profile management
•	AI-based compatibility scoring
•	AI-generated conversation starters
•	Real-time chat
•	Media uploads (images & videos)
•	Location-based matching
•	Pet meetup discovery

The architecture is designed to scale from MVP to millions of users while maintaining low latency, high availability, and production-grade security.

⸻

1. High-Level Architecture (HLD)

The system follows a microservices-based, cloud-native architecture deployed entirely on AWS.

Core Layers
1\.	Client Layer (Mobile + Web)
2\.	CDN & Edge Layer
3\.	API & Load Balancing Layer
4\.	Application Services (Containers)
5\.	Data Layer (SQL + NoSQL + Cache)
6\.	AI/ML Layer
7\.	Event-Driven & Async Processing Layer
8\.	Monitoring & Observability

⸻

1. AWS Infrastructure Architecture

3.1 Region & Availability

Primary Region: ap-south-1 (Mumbai)
Deployment across Multiple Availability Zones (Multi-AZ) for high availability.

⸻

3.2 Networking

Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)

Custom VPC configuration:
•	Public Subnets:
•	Application Load Balancer
•	NAT Gateway
•	Private Subnets:
•	ECS services
•	Isolated Subnets:
•	RDS Database

Security:
•	Security Groups for service isolation
•	Network ACLs
•	Internet Gateway
•	NAT Gateway for outbound traffic

⸻

1. Application Hosting Layer

4.1 Containerized Backend

Backend services are containerized using Docker and deployed on:

Amazon ECS with Fargate

Benefits:
•	Serverless container management
•	Automatic scaling
•	Reduced operational overhead

Containers stored in:
•	Amazon ECR

⸻

4.2 Load Balancing

Application Load Balancer (ALB)
•	Routes traffic to ECS services
•	SSL termination using AWS Certificate Manager
•	Health checks enabled

⸻

4.3 API Layer

Amazon API Gateway

Responsibilities:
•	Rate limiting
•	Throttling
•	JWT validation
•	Request transformation
•	WebSocket management (for chat)

⸻

1. Data Layer

5.1 Relational Database

Amazon RDS (PostgreSQL)

Stores:
•	Users
•	Pets
•	Matches
•	Subscriptions
•	Events
•	Relationship metadata

Configuration:
•	Multi-AZ deployment
•	Automated backups
•	Read replicas for scaling
•	Encryption at rest enabled

⸻

5.2 NoSQL Database

Amazon DynamoDB

Stores:
•	Swipe actions
•	Real-time chat messages
•	Online presence state
•	Activity logs

Features:
•	On-demand capacity
•	Global secondary indexes
•	Low-latency reads

⸻

5.3 Caching Layer

Amazon ElastiCache (Redis)

Used for:
•	Compatibility score caching
•	Frequently accessed profiles
•	Rate limiting counters
•	Online user tracking

⸻

1. Media & Static Content

6.1 Storage

Amazon S3

Stores:
•	Profile images
•	Pet images
•	Video uploads

Configurations:
•	Versioning enabled
•	Lifecycle policies
•	Server-side encryption

⸻

6.2 CDN

Amazon CloudFront

Delivers:
•	Static frontend assets
•	Profile images
•	Pet media

Benefits:
•	Reduced latency
•	Lower backend load
•	Edge caching

⸻

1. AI & Machine Learning Architecture

The AI layer powers compatibility scoring, content generation, and image analysis.

⸻

7.1 Text Generation

Integrated via:

Amazon Bedrock

Used for:
•	Conversation starters
•	Profile bio enhancement
•	Icebreaker suggestions
•	Chat improvement assistance

LLM prompts are orchestrated via backend service.

⸻

7.2 Compatibility Scoring Model

Hosted on:

Amazon SageMaker

Model Inputs:
•	Personality traits
•	Pet temperament
•	Activity frequency
•	Location proximity
•	Historical swipe behavior
•	Interaction patterns

Model Output:
•	Compatibility score (0–100)
•	Ranked recommendation list

Inference:
•	Real-time endpoint deployment
•	Autoscaling enabled

⸻

7.3 Pet Image Intelligence

Flow:

User uploads image →
Stored in S3 →
Event triggers AWS Lambda →
Lambda calls SageMaker endpoint →
Traits stored in database

Additionally:

Amazon Rekognition used for:
•	Animal label detection
•	Content moderation
•	NSFW filtering

⸻

1. Real-Time Chat Architecture

Chat uses:

API Gateway WebSocket API

Message flow:

Client → WebSocket → API Gateway →
ECS Chat Service → DynamoDB

Online status tracked in Redis.

Push Notifications:
•	Amazon SNS
•	Firebase Cloud Messaging integration

⸻

1. Event-Driven Architecture

Background and asynchronous tasks use:
•	Amazon SQS (Queue processing)
•	Amazon SNS (Event broadcasting)
•	AWS Lambda (Serverless execution)

Use Cases:
•	Image processing
•	AI inference
•	Notification triggers
•	Email dispatch
•	Analytics event streaming

⸻

1. Authentication & Authorization

Authentication handled by:

Amazon Cognito

Supports:
•	Email/Password login
•	Google login
•	Apple login
•	OTP verification

Security:
•	JWT-based authentication
•	Role-based access control
•	Multi-factor authentication
title: Pet dating app for pet lover

article.description:
Designed and implemented an enterprise grade AWS Glue Data Lakehouse to consolidate
fragmented booking and property data from legacy Oracle PMS and Track PMS into a single
governed analytics platform. Built scalable Bronze and Silver layers with incremental ingestion,
data standardization, and business transformations using Glue PySpark pipelines. 

Recently, I worked on designing a production-ready, highly available architecture on AWS — and here’s a simple breakdown of the setup.

markdownDescription:
Here is a concise executive summary of the AWS Data Agent Builder (Data Lake Implementation Project) based on your document  ￼:

⸻

AWS Data Agent Builder – Summary

1. Project Overview

Designed and implemented an enterprise-grade AWS Glue Data Lakehouse to consolidate fragmented booking and property data from:
•	Legacy Oracle PMS
•	Track MySQL PMS

The solution standardizes both systems into a single governed analytics platform using a Bronze–Silver architecture, enabling consistent revenue, occupancy, and performance reporting.

⸻

1. Architecture Overview

🔹 Core Stack
•	AWS Glue (PySpark notebooks) – Ingestion & transformations
•	Amazon S3 – Data lake storage (Parquet, Snappy)
•	Amazon Redshift – Data warehouse (Bronze & Silver schemas)
•	AWS Secrets Manager – Secure credential handling
•	IAM Role (glue-redshift-s3-datalake-access-role) – Central access control
•	GitHub – Version control
•	Power BI – Reporting layer

⸻

1. Data Layers

🥉 Bronze Layer (Raw + Standardized)
•	Source → S3 → Redshift Bronze
•	Incremental loads (T-1 or ID-based)
•	Schema normalization for Redshift compatibility
•	Timekey partitioning (YYYYMMDD)
•	ETL audit logging
•	Supports upsert & append logic

Purpose:
•	Preserve source structure
•	Maintain historical snapshots
•	Enable fast and auditable ingestion

⸻

🥈 Silver Layer (Business-Ready Model)

Transforms Bronze data into unified datasets:
•	Schema alignment (Legacy + Track)
•	Data enrichment
•	Business logic
•	Deduplication
•	Canonical data model
•	UNION of multiple source systems
•	Star-schema ready tables

Key Output Tables:
•	nr\_reservation
•	nr\_reservation\_breakdown
•	nr\_property
•	nr\_property\_type
•	nr\_resort
•	nr\_inventory\_night
•	Region & Unit dimensions

Result:
Single unified PMS data model for analytics.

⸻

1. Incremental & ETL Strategy
   •	Date-based incremental (T-1 loads)
   •	ID-based incremental loads
   •	Dynamic table creation
   •	Redshift COPY from Parquet (parallel optimized)
   •	Automated audit logging (bronze.etl\_audit\_log)

Benefits:
•	Faster runtime
•	Reliable batch consistency
•	Replay capability
•	SLA tracking

⸻

1. Security & Governance
   •	Secrets stored in AWS Secrets Manager
   •	Central IAM role for Glue, Redshift, S3 access
   •	Git-based version control (develop branch)
   •	No hardcoded credentials
   •	Audit logging for monitoring & reconciliation

⸻

1. Reporting & BI Layer

Power BI connected to Redshift (Analytics DB).

Reports:
•	RASS Report (Production-ready, minor inventory pending)
•	Company Goals Report (Completed)
•	Business Development Report (Partial backend dependencies)
•	Site Health Report (Dependent on Salesforce NPS data)

⸻

1. Key Business Outcomes
   •	Unified reservation & property model
   •	Standardized financial reporting
   •	Daily inventory availability tracking
   •	Scalable and secure architecture
   •	Faster analytics vs legacy systems
   •	Reduced manual reporting effort

⸻

Final Summary

The AWS Data Agent Builder solution delivers a secure, scalable, and analytics-ready Data Lakehouse on AWS, integrating multiple PMS systems into a single canonical model.

It enables:
•	Automated ingestion
•	Unified transformations
•	Governed data access
•	Enterprise reporting through Power BI
•	Production-grade monitoring and auditability

⸻

If you would like, I can also provide:
•	A 1-page resume summary version
•	A technical interview explanation version
•	A presentation slide version
•	A simplified non-technical business summary
•	An architecture diagram explanation

Let me know which format you need.
title: Building an intelligent data lake solution

markdownDescription:
GarAI is an AI-powered virtual assistant that includes a virtual try-on capability powered by the IDM-VTON model. This feature allows users to visualize clothing on human images with high realism. Hosting such a compute-intensive AI model requires a scalable and reliable cloud infrastructure, which is why AWS was chosen as the deployment platform.
Overview of the IDM-VTON Model
IDM-VTON (Implicit Dense Matching Virtual Try-On Network) is a deep learning–based virtual try-on model designed to preserve garment details while maintaining accurate body alignment. It focuses on:
Precise garment-to-body alignment
High-fidelity texture and fabric preservation
Reduced distortion in complex poses
These characteristics make IDM-VTON suitable for real-world fashion and e-commerce use cases.
Why AWS for Hosting IDM-VTON
Running IDM-VTON in production presents several challenges, including high GPU requirements, variable traffic, and low-latency inference expectations. AWS addresses these challenges by providing:
GPU-enabled compute instances for model inference
Elastic scaling to handle peak try-on requests
Managed storage and networking services
Built-in monitoring and security controls
AWS Architecture for GarAI Virtual Try-On
The IDM-VTON pipeline in GarAI is deployed using the following AWS components:
Compute and Model Hosting
Amazon EC2 GPU Instances are used to host the IDM-VTON inference service. These instances provide the necessary CUDA-enabled GPUs for fast image processing.
Inference services are containerized to ensure consistency across deployments.
API and Request Handling
Amazon API Gateway exposes a secure REST API that accepts user images and garment inputs.
AWS Lambda handles lightweight request validation, preprocessing triggers, and orchestration logic.
Storage Layer
Amazon S3 is used to store:
User-uploaded images
Garment images and metadata
Generated try-on results
Lifecycle policies are applied to manage storage costs efficiently.
Data Management
Amazon DynamoDB stores request metadata, job status, and processing results.
This enables fast lookups and asynchronous processing for longer-running inference tasks.
Monitoring and Reliability
Amazon CloudWatch tracks GPU utilization, inference latency, error rates, and request volume.
Alarms are configured to trigger auto-scaling or notifications when thresholds are exceeded.
Solving Real-World Challenges
Using AWS, GarAI addresses several practical issues associated with virtual try-on systems:
Scalability: Auto-scaling EC2 GPU instances ensures the system can handle spikes during high-traffic events.
Performance: Optimized inference pipelines reduce response time while maintaining output quality.
Cost Control: Spot Instances and S3 lifecycle policies help manage operational costs.
Reliability: Health checks and automated recovery improve service availability.
Security and Compliance
GarAI follows AWS security best practices:
IAM roles with least-privilege permissions
Encrypted data storage in Amazon S3
Secure API endpoints with authentication and throttling
Isolated networking using VPCs and security groups
Impact and Results
Hosting IDM-VTON on AWS has enabled GarAI to deliver:
High-quality, realistic virtual try-on experiences
Faster inference times compared to on-premise setups
Reduced operational overhead through managed services
A flexible foundation for future AI model upgrades
Future Enhancements
Planned improvements include:
Migration to Amazon SageMaker for managed model deployment
Batch inference support for large-scale fashion catalogs
Multi-region deployments for global latency optimization
Integration of feedback loops to improve model accuracy
title: GarAI: Building an AI Virtual Assistant on AWS to Solve Real-World Problems
